article.title: Conversion_of_units
article.paragraph: Conversion of unitsis the conversion between differentunits of measurementfor the samequantity, typically through multiplicativeconversion factors.
article.heading: Techniques
Process
article.paragraph: The process of conversion depends on the specific situation and the intended purpose. This may be governed by regulation,contract,technical specificationsor other publishedtechnical standardstandards. Engineering judgment may include such factors as:

list.listitem: Theprecision and accuracyof measurement and the associateduncertainty of measurement.
The statisticalconfidence intervalortolerance intervalof the initial measurement.
The number ofsignificant figuresof the measurement.
The intended use of the measurement including theengineering tolerances.
Historical definitions of the units and their derivatives used in old measurements; e.g.,international footvs. USFoot (unit)#Survey footsurvey foot.

article.paragraph: Some conversions from one system of units to another need to be exact, without increasing or decreasing the precision of the first measurement. This is sometimes calledsoft conversion. It does not involve changing the physical configuration of the item being measured.

By contrast, ahard conversionor anadaptive conversionmay not be exactly equivalent. It changes the measurement to convenient and workable numbers and units in the new system. It sometimes involves a slightly different configuration, or size substitution, of the item.Real versus nominal valueNominal valuesare sometimes allowed and used.
article.heading: Multiplication factors
article.paragraph: Conversion between units in themetric systemcan be discerned by theirSI prefixprefixes(for example, 1 kilogram = 1000 grams, 1 milligram = 0.001 grams) and are thus not listed in this article. Exceptions are made if the unit is commonly known by another name (for example, 1 micron = 106metre).
article.heading: Table ordering
article.paragraph: Within each table, the units are listed alphabetically, and theSIunits (base or derived) are highlighted.
article.heading: Tables of conversion factors
article.paragraph: This article gives lists of conversion factors for each of a number of physical quantities, which are listed in the index. For each physical quantity, a number of different units (some only of historical interest) are shown and expressed in terms of the corresponding SI unit.

article.heading: Plane angle

tablerow.tablecell: The angle subtended at the center of a circle by an arc whose length is equal to the circle's radius. One full revolution encompasses 2 radians.

article.heading: Solid angle

tablerow.tablecell: The solid angle subtended at the center of a sphere of radius r by a portion of the surface of the sphere having an area r2. A sphere encompasses 4 sr.

article.heading: Mass

list.listitem: SeeWeightfor detail of mass/weight distinction and conversion.
Avoirdupoisis a system of mass based on a pound of 16 ounces, whileTroy weightis the system of mass where 12 troy ounces equals one troy pound.
In this table, the unitgeeis used to denotestandard gravityin order to avoid confusion with the "g" symbol for grams.
Inphysics, thepound (mass)pound of massis sometimes writtenlbmto distinguish it from thepound-force(lbf). It should not be read as the mongrel unit "pound metre".

article.heading: Frequency

tablerow.tablecell: One unit rpm equals one rotation completed around a fixed axis in one minute of time.

article.heading: Speed or velocity

tablerow.tablecell: Ratio of the speed to the speed of sound#tag:ref in the medium (unitless).

article.paragraph: Avelocityconsists of a speed combined with a direction; the speed part of the velocity takes units of speed.

article.heading: Power or heat flow rate

tablerow.tablecell: The power which in one second of time gives rise to one joule of energy.

article.heading: Action

tablecell.extension: ''International System of Units,''8th ed. (2006),Bureau International des Poids et Mesures, Section 4.1 Table 7.

article.heading: Dynamic viscosity
Kinematic viscosity
Electric current

tablerow.tablecell: The constant current needed to produce a force of 2e-7newton per metre between two straight parallel conductors of infinite length and negligible circular cross-section placed one metre apart in a vacuum.

article.heading: Electric charge

tablerow.tablecell: The amount of electricity carried in one second of time by one ampere of current.

article.heading: Electric dipole

tablerow.tablecell: atomic unit of electric dipole moment

template.arg: The NIST Reference on Constants, Units, and Uncertainty

tablerow.tablecell: =val3.33564095-30C·mRobert G. MortimerPhysical chemistry,Academic Press, 2000 ISBN 0-12-508345-9, page 677

article.heading: Electromotive force, electric potential difference

tablerow.tablecell: The difference in electric potential across two points along a conducting wire carrying one ampere of constant current when the power dissipated between the points equals one watt.

article.heading: Electrical resistance

tablerow.tablecell: The resistance between two points in a conductor when one volt of electric potential difference, applied to these points, produces one ampere of current in the conductor.

article.heading: Capacitance

tablerow.tablecell: The capacitance between two parallel plates that results in one volt of potential difference when charged by one coulomb of electricity.

article.heading: Magnetic flux

tablerow.tablecell: Magnetic flux which, linking a circuit of one turn, would produce in it an electromotive force of 1 volt if it were reduced to zero at a uniform rate in 1 second.

article.heading: Magnetic flux density

table.tablecaption: What physicists callMagnetic fieldis calledMagnetic fluxdensity by electrical engineers and magnetic induction by applied mathematicians and electrical engineers.

tablerow.tablecell: = 104TStandard for the Use of the International System of Units (SI): The Modern Metric SystemIEEE/ASTM SI 10-1997. (1997). New York and West Conshohocken, PA:Institute of Electrical and Electronics EngineersandAmerican Society for Testing and Materials. Tables A.1 through A.5.

article.heading: Inductance

tablerow.tablecell: The inductance of a closed circuit that produces one volt of electromotive force when the current in the circuit varies at a uniform rate of one ampere per second.

article.heading: Temperature

tablerow.tablecell: frac273.16of thethermodynamic temperatureof thetriple point of water.

article.heading: Information entropy
article.paragraph: Often, information entropy is measured inShannon (unit)shannons, whereas the (discrete) storage space of digital devices is measured in bits. Thus, uncompressed redundant data occupy more than one bit of storage per shannon of information entropy. The multiples of a bit listed above are usually used with this meaning. Other times the bit is used as a measure of information entropy and is thus a synonym of shannon.
article.heading: Luminous intensity
article.paragraph: The candela is the preferred nomenclature for the SI unit.

tablerow.tablecell: The luminous intensity, in a given direction, of a source that emits monochromatic radiation of frequency 540e12hertz and that has a radiant intensity in that direction of 1/683 watt per steradian.
cd The use ofcandlepoweras a unit is discouraged due to its ambiguity.
Varies and is poorly reproducible.citationThe NIST Reference on Constants, Units, and Uncertaintyhttp://physics.nist.gov/cuu/Units/candela.htmlAugust 28, 2009Approximately 0.981 cd.

article.heading: Luminance

tablerow.tablecell: candela per square metre(SI unit); nit (deprecated)

article.heading: Luminous flux
Illuminance
Radiation - source activity

tablecell.extension: Ambler Thompson & Barry N. Taylor. (2008).''Guide for the Use of the International System of Units (SI)''.Special Publication 811. Gaithersburg, MD:National Institute of Standards and Technology. p. 10.

article.paragraph: Please note that although becquerel (Bq) and hertz (Hz) both ultimately refer to the same SI base unit (s1), Hz is used only for periodic phenomena, and Bq is only used for stochastic processes associated with radioactivity.citationhttp://www.bipm.org/en/si/si_brochure/chapter2/2-2/table3.htmlThe International System of Units, Section 2.2.2., Table 38[[Bureau International des Poids et Mesures]]2006August 27, 2009
article.heading: Radiation - exposure
article.paragraph: The roentgen is not an SI unit and theNational Institute of Standards and TechnologyNISTstrongly discourages its continued use.citationhttp://physics.nist.gov/Pubs/SP811/sec05.html#5.2The NIST Guide to the SI (Special Publication 811), section 5.22008August 27, 2009
article.heading: Radiation - absorbed dose

tablerow.tablecell: 1 J/kg = 1 m2/s2Ambler Thompson & Barry N. Taylor. (2008).''Guide for the Use of the International System of Units (SI)''.Special Publication 811. Gaithersburg, MD:National Institute of Standards and Technology. p. 5.

article.heading: Radiation - equivalent dose
article.paragraph: Although the definitions for sievert (Sv) and gray (Gy) would seem to indicate that they measure the same quantities, this is not the case. The effect of receiving a certain dose of radiation (given as Gy) is variable and depends on many factors, thus a new unit was needed to denote the biological effectiveness of that dose on the body; this is known as the equivalent dose and is shown in Sv. The general relationship between absorbed dose and equivalent dose can be represented as

whereHis the equivalent dose,Dis the absorbed dose, andQis a dimensionless quality factor. Thus, for any quantity ofDmeasured in Gy, the numerical value forHmeasured in Sv may be different.citationhttp://www.bipm.org/en/CIPM/db/2002/2/Comité international des poids et mesures, 2002, Recommendation 2August 27, 2009
article.heading: Software tools
article.paragraph: There are many conversion tools. They are found in the function libraries of applications such as spreadsheets databases, in calculators, and in macro packages and plugins for many other applications such as the mathematical, scientific and technical applications.

There are many standalone applications that offer the thousands of the various units with conversions. For example, thefree software movementoffers a command line utilityGNU unitsfor Linux and Windows.
